Designing the systems
that design products.

Keith Barney

Framing

A career crafting systems

I've spent 12 years moving from hands-on craft toward systems-level thinking. Each role gave me something new — startup ownership, team leadership and cross-platform architecture.

Here are three case studies showcasing my work and how I solve problems.

12+ years in design.

01

Case Study

From zero to company mandate

Creating Experian's first Design System

Case Study 01

Problem

No system.
No communication.

  • No design system
  • A style guide but no governance
  • Teams creating patterns independently
  • Inconsistent user experience

Case Study 01

Solution

Directly Owned

  • Design & Engineering Leadership buy-in
  • Slack support channels + intake workflows
  • Reusable component libraries
  • Base/alias token system architecture

Influenced

  • Designers creating domain-specific reusable components
  • Organization-wide shift toward systems thinking

Case Study 01

Key Decisions

Building buy-in with engineering

Engineering wasn't initially convinced a design system was worth the investment. I focused on showing the practical value — centralized decisions, reusable code, faster shipping, and built-in accessibility.

Knowing when to step back

Design QA was something I started, but it couldn't scale without more resources. I transitioned ownership to domain leads — a good lesson in knowing when to hand things off.

Helping designers work with the system

Worked with designers to show how overriding and detaching component instances created confusion downstream for developers.

Case Study 01

Impact

0 → 1

Design system created from scratch — first at Experian

3 platforms

iOS, Android, Web — unified component libraries

Company-wide mandate

Head of design mandated all new projects use Atlas

Team formalized

Keith + 2 native designers → first official DS team

Less custom code, fewer bugs

Engineering impact from centralized, reusable components

02

Case Study

Platform agnostic components

Merging Atlas components for Web, iOS and Android

Case Study 02

Problem

3 Component libraries.
3 Times the work.

  • Separate Web / iOS / Android Figma Libraries
  • Slightly different components for 3 platforms
  • Giant, confusing Figma files showing flows for each platform
  • Fixing bugs in 3 separate places

Case Study 02

Approach

Caleb and I co-owned this effort. We divided the component list, created branches, and merged and released in waves over about two months.

Formal deprecation process

Created a 4-step deprecation workflow: announce → migrate → sunset → remove.

Communication at every level

Slack announcements, Loom walkthroughs for breaking changes, 1:1 meetings with designers for check-ins and demos.

Getting leadership aligned

Brought Brett on board first, then Adam. Gave Adam a clear process and timeline he could use to communicate progress to leadership.

Visual

Case Study 02

Impact

1 component, all platforms

Same component works across iOS, Android, Web — fewer Figma frames

Centralized decisions

One source of truth replaced platform-specific interpretations

Team skill uplift

Designers' Figma skills greatly increased through migration process

Reduced switching cost

No more context-switching between platform-specific libraries

03

Case Study

Making adoption measurable

Creating Actionable Tools for Atlas Design System

Case Study 03

Problem

How do we prove the value of Atlas Design System?

  • Unclear design system adoption across teams
  • No visibility into highest-impact focus areas
  • Migration confusion between legacy and Atlas
  • Excess unused code accumulating in the codebase

Case Study 03

Solution

An internal tool that visualizes which UI system every element in production belongs to — turning abstract "adoption" into a concrete, prioritized backlog.

Directly Owned

  • Conceived and owned the idea end-to-end
  • Created Figma prototype for developer handoff
  • Collaborated with engineers for feedback loops
  • Ran the project autonomously with support from Brett and Adam

Influenced

  • Inspired team members to create their own internal tools
  • Shifted developer mindset — they started bringing ideas forward
  • Showed the value of identifying problems proactively, not just working from a backlog
Visual

Case Study 03

Impact

Tech debt → visible

Made invisible UI system debt concrete and actionable

Saved contract spend

Surfaced work for offshore team running low on tasks — prevented waste

Adoption operationalized

Abstract "adoption" became prioritized work items with clear ownership

Culture shift

Team started proactively building internal tools and bringing ideas forward

04

Case Study

Giving employees a voice

Co-founding and designing SpeakUp

Case Study 04

Problem

Good ideas with
no place to go

Important problems and ideas were scattered across organizations — buried in hallway conversations, lost in email threads, invisible to leadership. Companies had no structured way to surface what their own people already knew.

Hidden insights No structure Lost signal Top-down only
Visual

Case Study 04

Solution

Co-founded a workplace platform where employees post problems, propose solutions, and vote on ideas — turning scattered insight into concrete decisions for leadership.

Directly Owned

  • Product brand identity from scratch
  • Full web application UI — the core SpeakUp platform
  • Marketing site design and iteration
  • Led daily ceremonies and sprint management for 6 remote engineers

Influenced

  • Product strategy and feature prioritization as co-founder
  • Company culture — remote-first, shipping over perfection
Visual

Case Study 04

Impact

0 → shipped product

Designed and launched a SaaS platform from nothing — brand, UI, marketing

6-person remote team

Led distributed engineers through ceremonies, sprints, and releases

Real company adoption

Organizations used SpeakUp to crowdsource solutions and surface priorities

Still live today

Platform reached break-even and remains operational at getspeakup.com

05

Case Study

Paciolan Design System

First design system, team of six

Case Study 05

Problem

A team without
shared standards

Inherited a product with no design system and a team of six designers working independently. No formal review process meant inconsistent quality, duplicated work, and misalignment between design and engineering.

No design system Independent silos No review process Inconsistent quality
Visual

Case Study 05

Solution

Built the company's first design system while establishing a formal UX review process that created a shared quality bar across the team.

Directly Owned

  • First design system — patterns, components, shared language
  • Formal UX review process for the entire design team
  • Managed team of 6 through transition to systems thinking
  • Design-to-engineering communication standards

Influenced

  • Team mindset shift from ad-hoc design to shared standards
  • Balance between system consistency and designer autonomy
Visual

Case Study 05

Impact

0 → 1

First design system at Paciolan — built from nothing

Team of 6

Managed and mentored designers through the shift to systems thinking

UX review process

Shared quality bar — caught inconsistencies before engineering handoff

Reduced redundant work

Shared patterns replaced duplicate efforts across the team

The Arc

01 — Foundation

Built the system from zero

Created the first component libraries, established governance, and showed how a design system creates long-term leverage.

02 — Scale

Unified across platforms

Change management at scale. Merged fragmented libraries into a single cross-platform system.

03 — Innovation

Made adoption measurable

Noticed adoption was hard to track, so I built a tool that turned it into something concrete and actionable.

04 — Ownership

Co-founded and shipped a product

Designed the brand and product end-to-end, led a remote team, and launched a platform that companies actually adopted.

05 — Leadership

Built a team and a process

Led six designers, established the first design system and UX review process at Paciolan.

What I Bring

Systems thinker

I see how pieces connect across platforms and teams. I added a Design QA column to Jira that loops work between dev and design until approved — reducing follow-up tickets significantly.

Technical fluency

I speak developer language — tokens, components, versioning, build pipelines. That fluency makes collaboration smoother and helps me ask the right questions.

Business-minded

My startup background taught me to stay focused on customer value. I'd rather ship and learn than wait for something perfect.

Comfortable with healthy disagreement

I've learned to have honest disagreements without making things personal. It took time, but it leads to better outcomes.

I bring clarity to
complex systems.
